Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Significance of carbonyl compounds to photochemical ozone formation in a coastal city (Shantou) in eastern China.

AbstractText: Carbonyl compounds are ubiquitous in the troposphere, yet their contributions to ambient ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) formation have rarely been quantified in China. To better understand their roles in O<sub>3</sub> pollution, a field campaign was conducted at an urban site of Shantou, a coastal city in eastern China, during 7th-29th October 2019. Seven carbonyls were quantified (average ± standard deviation: 14.42 ± 3.05 ppbv), among which formaldehyde (4.12 ± 1.02 ppbv), acetaldehyde (1.57 ± 0.30 ppbv), acetone (7.55 ± 2.10 ppbv), and methyl ethyl ketone (0.94 ± 0.28 ppbv) were the most abundant species. Relative incremental reactivity (RIR) analysis indicated that O<sub>3</sub> formation in Shantou was VOC-limited, specifically most sensitive to carbonyls, and formaldehyde showed the largest RIR values in terms of individual species. Budgets of O<sub>3</sub> and RO<sub>x</sub> (OH, HO<sub>2</sub>, and RO<sub>2</sub>) radicals were elucidated with a chemical box model. Carbonyls played a vital role in both the primary formation and recycling of the RO<sub>x</sub>; more than 80% of the primary source of HO<sub>2</sub> and RO<sub>2</sub> came from photolysis of formaldehyde and other oxygenated VOCs. Zero-out sensitivity studies showed that the seven measured carbonyls accounted for 37% of the peak net O<sub>3</sub> production rate, mainly by affecting the concentrations of HO<sub>2</sub> and RO<sub>2</sub>. These results highlight the significance of carbonyls, especially formaldehyde, to photochemical O<sub>3</sub> formation, and carbonyls should be paid more attention to mitigate the worsening O<sub>3</sub> pollution in China.
